comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: Nice match with 1865 photo: and 1957 photo Mortuary Receiving Station No. 1 was designed by Colonial architect James Barnet who died in 1904 and is buried in the Presbyterian section of Rookwood Cemetery.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I wonder if this image is as old as the c.1865 one?  The stonework etc still looks relatively new and clean.

I didn't realize before that the Rookwood Station was literally a 'dead end'.  Did the trains have to reverse all the way from Redfern?

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: Some ninety (90) years between photos may be easier to date the Morning Coat worn or the in the sister photograph here "..On October 22 1864 the Rookwood Cemetery Railway Line opened. As the site at Haslem's Creek was some distance from the centre of Sydney it was decided to build a spur line and eventually four railway stations were built in the Cemetery grounds. Services ran twice a day for mourners and coffins until the late 1930s but was revived during World War II. The service was officially terminated in 1948..." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rookwood_Cemetery_railway_line Detailed train working described here en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cemetery_Station_No._4_railway_station Love the Victorian era’s fascination with death and the afterlife :). Powerful imagery – your journey ended with angels holding scrolls and trumpets as you arrived at your final destination

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Those angel sculptures symbolize Death and Resurrection, and the young sculptor, Thomas Duckett, died in 1868 as the building was nearing completion - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13166461 It seems the No.1 Mortuary Station was completed in 1869. See this wiki article - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cemetery_Station_No._1_railway_station which mentions a sign saying "commenced 14 April 1867, completed 10 August 1869". And this article in the SMH 22/4/1868 with description of how the building will look -
" ... The receiving-house at Haslem Creek is placed in the centre of the 200 acres set apart for the cemetery, and also in tho centre of an inner ring comprising 20 acres. The chapels to be erected by the several denominations will be around it. This building is a specimen of the Italian Gothic style, beautiful in proportion and ornamentation. It is a paralelogram, 98 feet 6 inches by 42 feet. This figure is divided longitudinally into three parts, a nave with side aisles, by two rows of circular columns, with richly-carved capitals. From these columns spring pointed arches, carrying the wall upon which rests the main roof. The sides of the building are entirely open. The rails will run through the nave, the side aisles and a portion of the nave forming platforms. The plain walls are built of 6-inch courses of rock faced work, pointed with black mortar. The whole of the interior timber work of the open roof will be painted in neutral tint, .picked out in primitive colours. The roof will be covered with slate in ornamental design, the entire length being terminated with an iron ridge cresting of quaint design. In these buildings it is difficult to say which is the most remarkable, the taste of the architect, Mr. Barnett, or the faithful and persevering skill of the general contractors, Messrs. Stoddard and Medway for Redfern, and Mr. Aaron Loveridge for Haslem Creek. ... "
I reckon all these photos are 1869, not "c.1865"

I have yet to find a Trove newspaper article about Pickering, Barnet & Co. having a photo day out at Rookwood / Haslems Creek,  but optimistic ...
